name: Celiprolol Evidence in Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
description: Celiprolol is a third-generation beta-blocker with unique beta-2 agonist properties that has shown efficacy in reducing cardiovascular events in vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. The landmark randomized controlled trial demonstrated significant reduction in arterial rupture and dissection. Celiprolol is now considered first-line medical therapy for vEDS, though the mechanism beyond standard beta-blockade remains incompletely understood. Availability varies by country.

content.statement: aku:vascular:genetic:eds-005-celiprolol is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Genetic-Ctd that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku:vascular:genetic:eds-005-celiprolol helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku:vascular:genetic:eds-005-celiprolol include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku:vascular:genetic:eds-005-celiprolol.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

celiprolol_pharmacology.administration: Take on empty stomach (food reduces absorption)

presentation: Family history of vEDS arterial events

design.population: vEDS patients with confirmed COL3A1 mutation

landmark_clinical_trial.conclusion: Significant reduction in arterial events with celiprolol

hemodynamic.reduced_dp_dt: Decreased rate of pressure rise in systole
hemodynamic.vasodilation: Beta-2 agonism may reduce peripheral resistance

potential_matrix_effects.hypothesis: May affect collagen synthesis or TGF-beta signaling

uncertain.question: Whether other beta-blockers would be equally effective

who_should_receive.indication: All vEDS patients with confirmed COL3A1 mutation
who_should_receive.age: Can be used in children (dose adjusted)

titration.increase: Gradually to 200 mg twice daily or maximum tolerated

united_states.access: Compassionate use, patient assistance programs, international pharmacy

contraindications: Severe asthma (beta-2 agonism may help, but caution)
cautions: Peripheral arterial disease (though vasodilation may help)

pregnancy.consideration: Limited data, discuss risks and benefits
pregnancy.general: Beta-blockers generally considered safe in pregnancy

common: Cold extremities (less than other beta-blockers due to beta-2 agonism)
side_effects.advantage_over_other_beta_blockers: Beta-2 agonism may reduce peripheral symptoms

ongoing: Heart rate and blood pressure at each visit

questions: Is celiprolol specifically better than other beta-blockers?
Are there molecular effects beyond hemodynamics?

comparison_with_marfan_treatment.difference: ARBs have evidence in Marfan but not specifically in vEDS

clinical_pearls: Celiprolol is the ONLY drug with RCT evidence in vEDS
60% relative risk reduction in arterial events in the Ong trial
Not FDA-approved in US - may require special access programs
If celiprolol unavailable, use conventional beta-blockers
learning_objectives: Summarize the evidence from the celiprolol trial in vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
Describe the unique pharmacologic properties of celiprolol
Apply celiprolol therapy in clinical management of vEDS

related.relationship: Similar concept of beta-blockade but different evidence base

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
